subject: Critical Thinking
title: Media Bias: Left, Right, and Structural
description: A micro-lesson that makes Media Bias: Left, Right, and Structural usable.

hook.text: Fox News and MSNBC report the same event. The facts overlap. The framing, emphasis, and omissions are wildly different.

buildup.text: Political bias (left/right) gets the most attention. But structural biases are more pervasive and harder to detect.

discovery.text: Structural biases: sensationalism, false balance, access bias, and status quo bias.

twist.text: False balance is dangerous: giving equal airtime to climate scientists & deniers implies a 50-50 debate.

punchline.text: Bias isn't the exception. It's the default. Read accordingly.

quiz.question: What is 'false balance' in media?
options: Giving equal weight to unequal positions, implying a debate where consensus exists
